comment.author: 61804295@N00
comment._content:
I have a shot of my class photo of 1952 or so, that I must scan and load. 

It features a teacher who has fond memories for me.. "Biscuit", we used to call him, as his name was Mr Arnott, of the famous family.  He took us all for a school excursion to the Arnotts factory in west Sydney, one of my first school excursions.

Mr Arnott taught us to sing "Ah Poor Bird, take thy flight..."  and "Drink to me Only"

My first experience of a pipe band was in the play-ground of the school, and of an Incinerator!!

We used to walk to school from Wyalong street, passing a shop that through a pavement level window, below street level, reminiscent of a Henry Lawson description in "Clancy..", I could see and smell the cutting of metal on lathes with white oil lubricant.  I later did Metal work at hi-school.
The shops where on the cnr of Mowbray Rd and Edward St.. Not far away was the Hallstrom factorym across from Burley Griffins Incinerator, I think.

On the way home, sometimes we would buy a penny icy-pole. Or once, Dad collected us half way home in the newly purchased Ford Prefect.

comment.author: 43246524@N06
comment._content: What Number Wyalong St did you live in?
